subject: Philosophy
title: Reductio ad Absurdum
description: A 60-second lesson on Reductio ad Absurdum.

hook.text: Assume the opposite of what you want to prove. If it leads to nonsense, your original claim wins.

buildup.text: Reductio ad absurdum is proof by contradiction. Mathematicians and philosophers use it constantly.

discovery.text: Euclid proved there are infinite primes this way. Assume finitely many; derive a contradiction; therefore infinite.

twist.text: In everyday arguments, it's equally powerful: 'If your claim were true, then this absurd thing would follow.'

climax.text: The elegance of reductio: you don't prove something directly. You show that denying it is impossible.

punchline.text: If the opposite is absurd, the original must be true.

quiz.question: How does reductio ad absurdum work?
options: By showing that denying a claim leads to a contradiction
By repeating a claim many times
